October 25, 1998: Fiction
BAG OF BONES, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) A series of terrifying events
besets a best-selling novelist four years after his wife's sudden death.
RAINBOW SIX, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) John Clark, heading an
international task force, investigates terrorist incidents in Switzerland, Germany
and Spain.
THE LOOP, by Nicholas Evans. (Delacorte, $25.95.) A biologist finds herself
facing professional and romantic problems while trying to protect wolves in
Montana.
THE REEF, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $23.95.) Searching for a jeweled amulet in
the depths of the Caribbean, a woman deals with mysteries and romance.
THE HUNDRED DAYS, by Patrick O'Brian. (Norton, $24.) In 1815, Jack Aubrey
and Stephen Maturin must intercept a shipment of gold intended to aid Napoleon.
TELL ME YOUR DREAMS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $26.) A series of brutal
murders that may involve three young women leads to a bizarre trial.
WELCOME TO THE WORLD, BABY GIRL! by Fannie Flagg. (Random House,
$25.95.) The pleasures and problems of the rising star of a 1970's television show.
I KNOW THIS MUCH IS TRUE, by Wally Lamb. (Regan Books/HarperCollins,
$27.50.) A troubled man must care for his schizophrenic identical-twin brother.
MEMOIRS OF A GEISHA, by Arthur Golden. (Knopf, $25.) The life of a young
woman growing up in Kyoto who has to reinvent herself after World War II begins.
BY THE LIGHT OF MY FATHER'S SMILE, by Alice Walker. (Random House,
$22.95.) The members of a black American family experience spiritual and sexual
enlightenment in the Sierras of Mexico.
SUMMER SISTERS, by Judy Blume. (Delacorte, $21.95.) Two young women from
very different backgrounds come of age together on Martha's Vineyard.
FIELD OF THIRTEEN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $24.95.) Thirteen stories of
suspense that revolve around the world of horse racing.
MESSAGE IN A BOTTLE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $20.) After finding a
seaborne bottle containing an enigmatic letter, a divorced woman encounters love.
BIRDS OF AMERICA, by Lorrie Moore. (Knopf, $23.) A dozen short stories that
center on articulate, erotically frustrated protagonists (usually women).
DAY OF CONFESSION, by Allan Folsom. (Little, Brown, $25.) A Hollywood
lawyer, in Rome to claim the body of his brother, a priest who has reportedly died

Non-Fiction
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
THE DEATH OF OUTRAGE, by William J. Bennett. (Free Press, $20.) The former
Secretary of Education takes a critical view of the Clinton Presidency.
THE TEN COMMANDMENTS, by Laura Schlessinger and Stewart Vogel. (Cliff
Street/HarperCollins, $24.) The radio talk-show host and a rabbi discuss the
significance of the Ten Commandments in contemporary life.
LINDBERGH, by A. Scott Berg. (Putnam, $30.) The checkered public and private
life of Charles A. Lindbergh.
PURE DRIVEL, by Steve Martin. (Hyperion, $19.95.) Humor pieces by the actor,
comedian and writer.
HIS BRIGHT LIGHT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $25.) The novelist recalls the
life of her son Nick Traina, who suffered from manic depression and died at 19.
JUST JACKIE, by Edward Klein. (Ballantine, $25.95.) The life of Jacqueline
Onassis from the assassination of President Kennedy to her death, 31 years later.
THE PROFESSOR AND THE MADMAN, by Simon Winchester. (HarperCollins,
$22.) How an American who was a certified lunatic and a murderer helped James
Murray compile the Oxford English Dictionary.
A PIRATE LOOKS AT FIFTY, by Jimmy Buffett. (Random House, $24.95.)
Traveling from Florida to the Amazon, the singer-songwriter reflects on his life.
EAT THE RICH, by P. J. O'Rourke. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) The humorist's treatise
on economics and the business world.
HIGH CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS, by Ann H. Coulter. (Regnery, $24.95.) A
lawyer states the case for the impeachment of President Clinton.
THE JOY OF WORK, by Scott Adams. (Harper Business, $22.) In words and
cartoons, the creator of ''Dilbert'' suggests ways to become happy by making your
co-workers miserable.
CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD: Book 1, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam,
$19.95.) The author addresses questions of good and evil, guilt and sin.
A WALK IN THE WOODS, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $25.) A journalist finds
beauty and humor while hiking the Appalachian Trail.
WORKING WITH EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE, by Daniel Goleman. (Bantam,
$25.95.) The attributes that enable people to become leaders in their fields.
